title: Who influenced Pierre de Fermat? - Quora

response.answer_text: Diophantus obviously because so much of Pierre’s work plays around with those equation forms, looking for answers and, perhaps more interestingly, non-answers. I’m not exactly sure how he became focused on what can’t happen, but it certainly is reflected in his general approach, and I think it reflects his essential ‘Frenchness’. To explain, the way he conceived of equations as having solutions or not, and defining those circumstances, is very much like the reflexive in French in which the concept of an object exists both independently of you and independently of itself. This allows the classic French discussions of what your ideal is versus my version, and arguments about which better reflects the context, need, etc. Relabel those as ‘solutions’ and the best solutions as those which are integers. I love that Pierre worked in probability because that also fits the French mind so well. I don’t mean anything restrictive by saying ‘mind’; I mean a strength of French mathematics is the way the language’s representation of reality is reflected in it.
